Fields.DialogueText: Lady Warspite! Lady Warspite, a word? If you please.
Captain?
Thank you. I've been meaning to catch you for some time, but our schedules just haven't seemed to align.
We've come through well enough.  What is it?

Fields.MenuText: Would you like to chat? I'd like to get to know you a little better.
I have a collection of bottled sunshine, and was wondering if you'd care to celebrate later.
I just wanted to say that I'm familiar with your career, and proud to be a part of this phase of it. That's all.

Fields.DialogueText: We're chatting already, are we not?
No, thank you, Captain, I'd prefer not to drink tonight.
Yes... thank you.
Of course... well, fantastic job that last battle! You handled well under heavy fire, and-
Handled?
"Worked" is probably the better word. I apologize.
No need, Captain. Please, if you could maybe leave me be? We should both prepare for our upcoming action.
... If you say so.
@BATTLE
Captain?
Yes, Lady Warspite?
Warspite is adequate, Captain. I want to apologize for our last conversation.

Fields.MenuText: You *were* quite rude there.
You're the most important part of our crew, Warspite. I can't have you getting distracted.
I completely understand. We all need a moment to think sometimes.

Fields.DialogueText: Mm. It wasn't my intent.
I daresay you're right. But sometimes I don't want to be found.
I appreciate it, Captain. Such moments for me are... frequent.
I can't order you to get out of your head, but it'd do you some good. Go spend some time with the rest of the crew. They'd enjoy seeing you.
I'm not sure about that, Captain. I don't speak much to the rest of the crew... or even notice them, really.
You're a Belle, aren't you? Can't you hear everything aboard this washtub?
I am a battleship, Captain. I'll thank you to refer to me as such.
Noted - I'm sorry to have offended. I'm still getting used to all this.
Perhaps we should have discussed our expectations of one another when I chose you as my Captain.
What are some of the things you expect of me?
That you handle yourself professionally.  My greatest respect lies with those who treat the profession of war with the utmost gravity.
That's fair. You were commissioned as part of the Grand Fleet during the last war, obviously. I imagine you've had a... wide range of experiences with your officers.
You've studied me?
I find it important to know who I'm working with, Warspite.
I'd expect nothing less. Now, what are some of the things you expect of me?
Treat the crew with respect, and follow orders. You're an experienced sailor; I know I can trust you with this.
Morganas ahead, Captain. A fine opportunity to live up to each other's expectations.
@BATTLE
Apologize? What for?
I was a bit brusque with you, Captain. I was lost in thought.
"All this?"
When I look at you, I see the person in front of me. I'm used to thinking of a ship as a thing I can affectionately insult.
I *am* the ship, Captain. I expect you not to insult me.
That's a fair expectation.
Load the torpedoes! And have ammunition ready!
Do you sense Morganas?
Not at the moment, but I'm readying myself to fight all the same.
I'm practicing naval tactics. Watch and learn, Captain.

Fields.MenuText: You can't live in fear, Warspite.
You're paranoid, Warspite. This isn't good for you.

Fields.DialogueText: I'm calm as a summer's day, Captain. Are *you* afraid?
If I've chosen a captain who counsels against readiness, I'm clearly delusional anyway.
Warspite, your hands are shaking. This is *not*-
Quiet! Do you feel that?
... No, of course not. Why would you?
Warspite?
I was right to be prepared, Captain. Look to starboard. Morganas approaching.
Broken clocks...
@BATTLE

Fields.MenuText: A Belle's instincts are good, but they're not infallible.

Fields.DialogueText: Unless your compass has also awakened, I think it prudent you defer to me on such matters.
This lesson isn't worth teaching.
What?
The sea's clear as far as the eye can see. There's vigilance, and then there's hypervigilance.
We are at *war*. Vigilance is *prudent*.
We should talk, Captain.
Just a moment-
Captain–
You're normally so jumpy about Morganas, but we're picking up enemies ten klicks away. Why didn't you sense them?
Go prep the guns.
@BATTLE
Can we have that discussion now, Captain?
Of course. What is it?
Regarding our earlier tiff... it's hard for me to respect someone who doesn't show the utmost respect for tactics.

Fields.MenuText: You're wonderfully capable. But you're so... keen... that you can't trust me the way you ought to.
If you're going to make my crew live in fear, we're not going to see eye to eye. I'll try to trust your judgement, but...

Fields.DialogueText: You'll take my trust for granted when I can take your judgment for granted, Captain.
You'll try? I suppose it was rank optimism to have proposed this dynamic in the first place. If you don't trust my judgement-
Well? What do you think we should do about this?
I'm not sure.
I thought as much.
Excuse me?
I apologize. That was rude. I want to... I just feel I need to express my frustration with this matter.
Of course. I'll put some more thought into this and talk to you again when I'm ready to discuss further.
Thank you, Captain.
I will do my best to listen to orders and look out for you, but I struggle to trust you if you don't apprise yourself of my capabilities.

Fields.MenuText: I'm concerned about your mental state. When you say you're lost in thought, you look shell-shocked.

Fields.DialogueText: Hardly. I want to stay alive. When I'm lost in thought, you can trust I'm planning the best ways to do it.
I'm surprised, Warspite.
I suppose I was lost in thought again.
... It's not your capabilities I'm worried about.
I beg your pardon?
Trust goes both ways, 'Spite. I can't trust you if you don't trust me.
We must talk.
I agree, but there's a battle on the way, so it will have to wait.
@BATTLE
What's wrong?
The crew all went drinking before they finished restocking the torpedoes.
You and I discussed your "vigilance" problem. Do you remember that conversation?
I know. This isn't over-preparation, Captain. Nobody's available to tend to them now. If we're caught off guard-

Fields.MenuText: The crew can't work all hours of the day, Warspite. They need breaks from time to time.
Can't you help?

Fields.DialogueText: Our safety should come first.
I shouldn't have to. This shouldn't have happened in the first place.
No one has been hurt and nobody's around, so I'll take care of it. It was a small mistake.
The smallest mistakes can have the deadliest effects, Captain. Whatever happens to us, we are not having another Battle of Jutland. I'm certain I don't have to elaborate.

Fields.MenuText: I can make an announcement about it.

Fields.DialogueText: See that you do, Captain. I will not be caught unprepared by the enemy.

Fields.MenuText: I wrote a dissertation on Jutland.

Fields.DialogueText: Then you know the stakes. Keep your crew in line before I'm forced to.
There's always a battle on the way.

Fields.MenuText: No. You don't. I know your history.
Given that we still haven't totally fixed your steering twenty-odd years later... no. Your point is taken.

Fields.DialogueText: The crew didn't appreciate your announcement.
You were going to let this go.
Leaving notes by their bedsides while they're asleep is–
Detailed critiques and recommendations of corrective action. Frankly, I wish I were surprised you'd decided against both.
The crew have been working hard. They earned that break, Warspite.
And if someone had gotten hurt because they hadn't finished their work, they would have deserved that as well.

Fields.MenuText: I stand behind my decision.
Why are you getting so worked up over this?
I thought this discussion was finished.

Fields.DialogueText: I suppose your responsibility must begin somewhere.
Next time you're left alone on the operating table, incisions gaping like crevasses, you'll think back on this conversation and understand.
We never came to a consensus. Namely, mine.
This is not a conversation. You're disobeying a direct order. At the *very* least, I want an apology.
But will you apologize?
I took responsibility.
The fact that you won't comply with my request is disrespectful to me, Captain.
How so?
Putting oneself in danger is one thing, but putting me in peril is altogether different! A truly responsible captain would never have let this happen.
Warspite, if we'd been in any danger-
We're in danger *now*. I sense Morganas approaching. What good fortune we're awake for it.
@BATTLE
Apologize for what?
For abdicating responsibility.
@BATTLE
Warspite?
Yes, Captain, what is it?
I'd like to discuss our disagreement over the crew.
I'm not in the mood for such discussions right now.

Fields.MenuText: I'm trying to be polite, you know. The least you could do is listen.
But I'm ready to talk.
It's been a while since we last spoke of this matter.

Fields.DialogueText: No, the least I could do is ignore you.
And I am not. Please leave me.
And this is the *worst* possible time you could have chosen to bring it up.
Please, I need to say this.
Have you never heard of actions speaking louder than words?
My point in its entirety-
All right, I understand.
Hmm... yes, that will do.
What's that?
My torpedo bays are in *excellent* condition. Seems I've terrified the crew into adequacy, or at least something resembling it.
... I request some time alone to think on this, Captain. Do me that courtesy.
Please.
Warspite, if you'd-
Leave the terrifying to the Morganas.
One must learn from their enemies to defeat them. The Morganas certainly aren't getting any more human.
Load the guns! Let's see how much of a challenge these Morganas are!
... and after the battle, be sure to put your toys away before grabbing that bottle of sunshine.
@BATTLE
Thank you, sir.
I'm sorry?
For your announcement about the crew's... toys. They were the very model of professionalism.
I'm glad you see it that way.  Once they knew how you felt, there really wasn't any other choice.
Yes, and I shall apologize to the crew for my invasion of their privacy.

Fields.MenuText: Well, it's about time.
Thank you for that.
I know they'll be as receiving of you as they are of me.

Fields.DialogueText: We're coming to an understanding, Captain. No need for that.
Terror grows dull without mercy to sharpen it.
I hope so. Thank you, Captain.
The crew are lucky, you know. Certain of my sisters would have made examples of them.
I'm afraid to ask.
We Belles are all dedicated in our own way... however violent.
Be glad *I* am the one who chose you, Captain. Others could be much, much worse.
Come on, folks, no time to rest! We've got company!
@BATTLE
Captain, if you keep this up, I may start to trust you.
You already trust me to lead the crew. And I'm glad we've started seeing eye to eye.
The trust they have in your leadership is undeniable.
I appreciate you saying that, Warspite.
I appreciate you putting it to use.
It's the nature of the office. You're part of my crew, my family at sea, just as the cadets and lieutenants are.
I'm glad you can say that so easily.
I'll protect you with my life, just as I will the rest of the crew. The proof of the pudding is in the eating, yes?
Thank you, Captain. We certainly ate well today.

Fields.MenuText: How do you think we'll fare for the rest of this war?
I hope we outlast this war and not vice versa.
Just trying to do my part.

Fields.DialogueText: I think better of our efforts. But we're just one piece of it all.
We shall, as long as you have faith.
You're a credit to God, King, and country.
You understand the importance of a unified command structure, then. I'm concerned for the future, but I can't let my crew see that.
I may not know much outside of battle strategies and ship maintenance, but I know enough about people to be hopeful for what we have.
... Thank you, for your faith in me.
I have faith in the powers above, but I have trust in men and women of excellence.
What was that noise?
The crew did it again.
The torpedoes? Was one launched by mistake?
Yes, and Cadets Hall and Moore... bit the dust, as you'd say.
What happened?
Both stuck an arm in the breech door; thought it'd be funny. It wasn't.
Also, I believe the noise may have alerted some Morganas to our location.
Attention, crew! We have a man down. Get Lt. Taylor and the medics to the torpedo room, now.
@BATTLE
So what shall be done about the earlier incident?

Fields.MenuText: On behalf of the entire crew, I apologize for their actions.
Are you all right?
A mistake that will not be tolerated  or repeated.

Fields.DialogueText: Let them show their repentance as well.
My body betrays me. I invite you to speculate.
Those responsible will be accountable for their actions.
I'll deal with it. Decisively.
See that you do.
Your hands are shaking again.
Mm. You *will* treat this situation with the seriousness it deserves, I presume.
My hands may shake now, but when I have use of them again... You will *wish* I had chosen indecision.
Warspite, we are being raided! Get ready for battle!
Warspite, focus!
@BATTLE
Warspite! Warspite!
... Indefatigable....

Fields.MenuText: What's the matter with you?
Warspite? Can you hear me?
The Battle of Jutland? During the Great War?

Fields.DialogueText: Indefatigable... I saw the black smoke...
Bring... bring back the men. A thousand and seventeen...
North Sea... so much metal at the North Sea.
Oh... oh, no...
I can't, Captain, I can't...
I've seen this before! Please, you need to breathe. Breathe in...two... three... four... five...
Where is she, Captain? Where's Indefatigable?
HMS Indefatigable served with honor. She's in a better place now.
I want to join her.
One day, you will, but not yet. We have responsibilities to take care of here and now.
So... so Von der Tann... I'll sink that bitch myself!
Von der Tann sunk in 1919. She's not gonna hurt you. You're safe.
Yes?
I'm sorry. I lost my composure for a moment. Thank you for your assistance, Captain.
Of course. Let me know if you need anything else. You're sure you're all right?
Most definitely. I'll be taking my leave now.
What?
...my friends... The coast of Jutland...
Hold... two... three... four... five...  Out... two... three... four... five.
... Her hands are still shaking...
You wanted to see me, Captain?
Yes, I wanted to see how you were holding up.
Fine. Thank you for your concern.

Fields.MenuText: I'm worried about you.
You sure? You definitely had some shell shock back there.
I've never seen you so... so out of your depth.

Fields.DialogueText: I appreciate the sentiment, but I assure you, I'm fine.
My composure eluded me. Then I regained it. There's nothing to worry about.
Sometimes I get too caught up in thought, and I remember an old friend. That's all that happened.
If you ever need to talk, I'm here.
If I ever need to discuss this with you, which I am almost certain I won't, I shall be cordial.
... That's nice to hear.
For now, we have work to do.
@BATTLE
Another set of Morganas are inbound! Get ready to send them packing, people!
Are you all right, Warspite?
I'm... I'm just fine... Captain.
@BATTLE
... Indefatigable...
Is everything all right?
Nothing!

Fields.MenuText: Their deaths weren't in vain.
We can't have everything, Warspite.
The Battle of Jutland was a tragedy.

Fields.DialogueText: Soldiers around me die every day. It already has been in vain.
I could've tried harder.
And one I co-authored.
... We have to push forward, Warspite. We keep living. For them, and for us.
I'm a battleship in the middle of a war, Captain. There's nothing I can do but push forward.
... You are. And you're also the person who's here in front of me. So if you need to talk...
It was just a moment of weakness. I'm sorry. I'll do better to control my spirits... and to have faith.
I think if you talked about it, you'd feel better.
Not right now. I'm still... I'm still... stuck.
I'll be here. If you ever want to get it off your chest...
If... if that time ever comes... I'll keep that in mind.
(...Oh no.)
You ask me that question *now*, of all times?
Well... Yes. You seem a bit upset.
Of course I'm upset. I - I -
Nothing?
Nothing's all right! My. My friends. My friends.
Steady now, Warspite. You're safe here.
My friends. Are dead. And it's my fault. They're dead.  How can you ask me if I'm all right?
Warspite, we have Morganas incoming! We need to get in line!
... Light the signal lamps, then.
@BATTLE
We need to talk.
You've only known me for a short time. What do you know of my average performance?
You kept veering starboard when it wasn't necessary.
I was concerned for the safety of the crew.
I am, too.  Which is why we need to talk about this.
I'm fine.

Fields.MenuText: I'm concerned about you and about my crew. Warspite, listen to me-
You're anything but fine.
For pity's sake, you're fighting a battle you can't win.

Fields.DialogueText: No, *you* listen to *me!*
I'm doing my best with the cards I've been dealt!
We're all fighting the Morganas. There's nothing to discuss.
Listen up, Warspite. As your captain, I *can't* let you keep doing this.
Command won't like that. You're taking a perfectly good ship out of commission-
Never mind Command!
You're taking a minor slip-up very seriously, Captain. I wasn't insubordinate, and no one died because of my actions.
You are as important to me as she was to you. And that means I want to help you.
You're the only one I'd want to tell, and... you've studied Jutland. It's nothing you don't already know.
It's different if I hear it from you.
Mm. Very well, then.
We don't use those anymore.
I thought you said you would wait until I was ready.
I did. But your performance in this last battle was... disquieting.
We do *not*.
Keep doing *what*?
Right now, you are medically unfit for battle. If you were a human sailor, I'd be sending you to Leopardstown Hospital.
But I'm not human, and you *can't* do that.
You're right. I don't think you'd fit through the door. --But the point stands.
You are so badly shell-shocked that it's affecting your ability to fight.
I can't force you to get better. But I can't put your life, or the lives of my crew, at risk because you're not well.
Either you get a hold of yourself- with me, with a friend, with a psychoanalyst, I don't care- or you sit in drydock for the rest of the war.
... I hate to do this to you, but...
I don't want you, or any of the other Belles in our fleet, to wind up like Indefatigable.
How *dare* you bring her into this?!
As your friend, you don't have to tell me anything you're not comfortable with. As your Captain... you need to talk about this with *someone*.
Holding it in is poisoning you. And I can't be responsible for what happens if you don't get that poison out of your system.
If you really want to hear what happened... I suppose it's between you, me, and God, isn't it?
I'll keep your secrets.
... Here's what I remember, then...
Six thousand men, all dead... I'm sorry you had to experience such a tragedy, Warspite.
Admiral Jellicoe did eventually lead the fleet to prevent German access to Great Britain and the Atlantic. Their deaths weren't *entirely* in vain.
I read that he received a lot of negative attention due to the number of casualties.
The bastard deserved it. -- To a degree.

Fields.MenuText: Are you biased in that statement?
Is it because he couldn't lead your friends to safety?
But we achieved our long-term goals after the battle.

Fields.DialogueText: Fourteen ships were lost, so you'll forgive me on that front.
The ships that were taken down were fighting two at once. Long odds, but they were gambled.
At what cost?
You saw so many of your friends and sisters taken away...
If there's anything I can do for you, just let me know. I'm here for you.
I feel... I feel better now that we've spoken. Thank you, Captain.
I just want you to be at your best. We're all safer when you are.
Let's put that to the test. Morganas approaching!
@BATTLE
It is, quite literally, what I was made for. And one could say it wasn't a total waste.
We weren't people to him. And neither were the men aboard. When it comes to strategy, you have to be willing to make those sacrifices.
I suppose you're right.
Something wrong?
....No, I just ... hm.
... Was it my fault, or his, Captain?
What do you think?
... I've blamed myself this entire time. I still feel like I'm the one to blame.
But... we were all sleepwalking, weren't we? Following orders. ....It can't have been *all* my fault. It feels like it. But it can't have been.
No, it can't. You've taken on a burden that's too heavy for anyone to bear. And it wasn't yours to take to begin with.
Don't thank me. All I did was listen.
... But that's what I needed most, Captain.
Warspite, would you join me for a moment?
Absolutely, as soon as we deal with the Morganas nearby.
@BATTLE
Care to share a drink with me, Warspite?
One.

Fields.MenuText: We don't do this nearly enough. What with the war stressing us all out, it's a wonder how I'm not always drunk.

Fields.DialogueText: Drinking your problems away will bring you closer to death, Captain.
Well, you don't have to kill the mood. Whatever comes next can't be worse than the Morganas.
Hm. Heaven or hell, depending on your faith. Do you like those odds, Captain?

Fields.MenuText: I'm not Christian, so I won't make that bet.
I'm hoping for Heaven, but I'm not the one who makes that call.
Oh, I know I'm going to hell. Might as well have some fun getting there.

Fields.DialogueText: That's surprising. I thought you were a very faithful person.
If I were, you'd pass the Pearly Gates without a problem.
We can always repent of our sins.
... Well. I can't think of a heaven that'd be better than being here with my crew. You, most of all.
You don't miss a thing.
I know when there are enemies within range. Admiral Beatty could have learned a thing or two from me.
"Faith" and "Christianity" are two very different things.
The way you say that... Is that what's kept you going this long?
... Sometimes I wish you were less perceptive.
That's kind of you.
That can't be right.
I really enjoy your company, Warspite.
And I enjoy yours. But I'm sure you'd like it better if there wasn't a war on.
Maybe I like war.
Maybe you're a fool. But you know what they say.
"God protects drunks, fools, children..."
"...And the good ship Warspite?"
Oh, *hush*.

Fields.MenuText: It's only water.

Fields.DialogueText: I'm immersed in the stuff all day.
Morganas on the port side! Everyone, to your stations!
Yes, sir!
@BATTLE
Tea, sir?

Fields.MenuText: Milk and two sugars.

Fields.DialogueText: No accounting for taste. I suppose I'll have to forgive you.

Fields.MenuText: I completely concur.
That's no excuse to be complacent and comfortable. We still have a war to win.
Who knows what'll become of us?

Fields.DialogueText: And I appreciate the time I've gotten to spend with you. You've pleasantly surprised me.
That's correct, but having hope doesn't hurt.
I suppose only God above does.
You give me hope, too. I believe we'll have success in our endeavors, now and in the future. Because I believe in you. And.. I trust you.
Let's make a toast. To trust?
I'm glad we can give each other hope. You certainly do wonders with it.
... But I have to thank you. I've grown a lot calmer recently, and I'm very hopeful for our future. I think our efforts will be very fruitful.
Thank you. It really feels like a weight has been lifted, Captain.
To trust. And to lifting weights.

Fields.MenuText: No, thank you.
Nothing in it, I hope.

Fields.DialogueText: Are you suggesting I would use milk and sugar without provocation? Captain, I'm almost insulted.
They snuck up on us! Everyone, to your stations! Move, now!
@BATTLE
Medic! Somebody get Lt. Taylor and his team in here. Warspite needs them!
Derfflinger... and Seydlitz... they... they murdered her, and I didn't arrive in time to help...
Warspite! Warspite, I need you with me.
Seeing the crew hurt earlier might have stressed you, but I need you to breathe again. Inhale and exhale.
I can't... I can't protect everyone... Reinhard Scheer will come for us all...

Fields.MenuText: Medics! To my side, now!
Reinhard Scheer is dead, Warspite.
Nobody's coming for you. We're here to protect you.

Fields.DialogueText: If not the Germans, then the Morganas...
But who's protecting Indefatigable?
Listen to me. Warspite. The Great War's over. You *won*.
... They're lost....
If Lt. Taylor doesn't arrive in the next minute, I will remove him from this vessel myself!
They're... they're coming. For me.
No! We've lost so many already!
They're both here, Captain. Can't you see them?
You're safe, Warspite. You know that, right? No one is coming for you.
I don't think anyone's coming for me, Captain. I'm sorry for misleading you.

Fields.MenuText: It happens, I suppose. But we need to figure out how to solve this.
The crew get hurt all the time. You need to pull yourself together.
I was scared half to death when I realized I couldn't help you myself.

Fields.DialogueText: I know. I shouldn't lose composure so quickly.
I need to learn to accept that. I'm sorry.
I would have preferred to have you there than not, though I understand if you aren't.
I do hope you're feeling better.
I am. Thank you.
When you're feeling up for it, I have a present for you.
How gallant of you, Captain.
Before we met, I read your file and found you hail from Cornwall. In our travels together, I may have picked up a bottle of Cornish scrumpy...
You have a bottle of scrumpy!? Captain... I am a woman of few vices, but you tempt me utterly.
I believe you've finally drawn me into one of your celebratory moods. After these Morganas fall, we shall toast our victory.
@BATTLE
Even Jesus drank wine.
Warspite, we have a battle to deal with.
@BATTLE
The crew... the crew were hurt again...
It'll all be all right, Warspite. Lt. Taylor and the medics are taking them to the infirmary to be patched up.
I could have, maybe... manoeuvred out of the way from fire, and–
Your actions were honorable and timely. You saved lives by focusing on the battle at hand.
I could have tried–
No one can avoid injuries, but your actions in our time together have saved lives.
I've made mistakes before... before I awoke. It's in my nature to-

Fields.MenuText: They're in the past. You need to move away from that.
They're irrelevant to what you do here today.
Let Indefatigable guide your actions now.

Fields.DialogueText: Tell that to the thousands who can't!
Not if I haven't learned from them!
She always will. Her, and Queen Mary. I just hope I haven't failed them...
I understand that everything you do now is a direct result of what happened on that day. But you can't let it interfere with your mission.
You're... you're right. And I can't protect everyone.
But you can do your best, and so will we.
Thank you for your support in my time of need, Captain. I... I've been letting what happened keep me in fear for so long.
We're all afraid of some things, Warspite. I think it takes a lot of bravery to admit and face those fears.
And a lot of courage to help others with them as well. You don't know if I'll just-
It's war. It doesn't matter if it's against ghost ships or the ghosts of your past. We may only drive them off, but until we figure out how to do more, that's enough.
... My steering was damaged. It wasn't my fault. My steering was damaged. It wasn't my fault...
... I think I'll be having some of that scrumpy now. Join me?
Of course.
Hey, Warspite. I've got something for you. It's from the crew. A token of appreciation.
That's... that's extremely kind of them. What is it?
If you look at the helm, you'll see the likeness of St. Piran.
And they... they hung the flag of Cornwall for me?

Fields.MenuText: They care for you just as much as I do.
They want you to know how much they care for you. Just as much as you do for them.
To make you feel more welcome, and to feel more in the present.

Fields.DialogueText: That makes me feel... very connected to them. Thank you.
I hope knowing that doesn't make my episodes worse.
This gesture of solidarity is too much.
They're worried for your well-being.
And I am for theirs. I shall prove it to them.
I happened to dig up a copy of my dissertation. You know what else happened that day?
Captain, please-
What happened to Warrior?
She sank.
After you drew fire from her and let her escape. You saved over seven hundred lives, Warspite.
Captain, that wasn't me. They... they'd hit my engines, I couldn't turn left-
- And that was when you were damaged. Imagine what you can do in peak condition.
... I suppose I don't have to. I've been doing it, haven't I? You've kept me in shape and I just... never bothered to appreciate it.
I'm not offended.
Not you, Captain. Me. It's... I'll join you in another celebration next time. It may take a few to really... stick.
That's all right. I can wait.
@BATTLE
I wanted to apologize to you, Captain.
What for? You haven't done anything wrong.
When we first met, I told you I didn't trust you. I'm sorry. You're so much more than what I initially thought.
I need to know that we're all up to the fight. What I do for you I'd do for anyone else aboard you.
I'm honoured, Captain. Truly.
And if we keep doing right by each other, the war will be much shorter.
With you to lead us, that's highly probable.

Fields.MenuText: And with you at my side, I think we can do anything.
As long as we keep communicating, nothing will stand in our way.
I am a wonderful leader, thank you.

Fields.DialogueText: Whatever providence brought us together will see us through to the end.
I will do better to be more open about my problems.
All the cheek I wasn't built with. You complete me.
Warspite, you've really inspired me to work harder at being the captain of this vessel.
I have been in this business for a while now. I might have rubbed off on you.
You probably have, but it's for the better.
The way you handle these... attacks of mine... I think it shows great character and leadership.
Handle?
Sorry, work with these attacks.
@BATTLE
You're forgiven. And speaking of attacks...
Morganas inbound. Prepare for battle.
Let me communicate with them.
You don't usually talk to them.
Today I do.
Attention! You will not be hurting my family today! Heed my warning and turn back now, or face our wrath!

Fields.MenuText: That didn't really seem necessary.
Where did that come from?
Thank you for your kind words.

Fields.DialogueText: I can't speak for them, Captain, but it certainly buoyed me.
From my compassion for the crew and for you, of course.
They are every one of them true.
Let's see if your warning scares them into submission.
We will be ready if it does not.
@BATTLE
Lt. Taylor took the men to the infirmary. One of the cadets might need an amputation, but everyone's still breathing.
I'm... I'm fine. Just fine.
That's great. You're making progress.
Do you think I'm becoming desensitized to all this, in some way?

Fields.MenuText: No, war is war and injuries happen. And they affect us all.
In a way, yes. But we can't stop and grieve for everyone who is hurt.
Yes, it is. Unfortunately, that's the reality of combat.

Fields.DialogueText: I wish there were some way to... to do this without that.
They'll just have to settle for our prayers.
That is true. I've been in battles for so long, but I've never really accepted that reality.
We can get through this.
Yes, I know we can. I just hope all of the crew do too.
Are you all right?
Does that sound desensitized to you?
It doesn't at that, Captain. I suppose my mind's elsewhere lately than it has been.
Do you like it there?
I'm learning to.
Look. Your hand...
... Hm? It's not shaking.
You could build a tower on there and it'd stay standing.
Let's start with a foundation.
I got more scrumpy. Care to have a glass once we show the Morganas what a Royal Navy ship is capable of?
There's nothing I'd rather do.
@BATTLE
One day, I'll learn how to brew this on my own.
It does cost quite a bit. But apparently some friends of Lugin's can get us a better price if I start buying in real volume.
You haven't been buying in real volume all along? You still have so much to learn.

Fields.MenuText: I'll trade you for that tea you've been making.

Fields.DialogueText: But I digress. Things are really looking up for us. War is war, but I believe we'll be successful in the future.

Fields.MenuText: Yes, I agree. I think... you and me? We're going to be great friends.
Maybe... maybe successful in our personal lives as well?

Fields.DialogueText: Even if... even if we don't outlast this war, at least our friendship will.
I'll drink to that. To our future!
At least you can reuse the leaves. Drink this and it's gone.

Fields.MenuText: I could get used to this.

Fields.DialogueText: Someone has to keep you responsible, and I am happy to volunteer.

Fields.MenuText: I'm curious... can Belles get drunk?

Fields.DialogueText: I shouldn't think so, in the normal way at least. Perhaps if my cargo were flooded...
